However, the following are some basic reasons why certain accounts or items are not generally funded to a Living Trust.
Checking account balances generally (and regularly) fluctuate. Having a Pour-Over Will as a supporting document to a Living Trust allows a person to leave the remainder of the estate that is not transferred into the trust (for example, checking accounts) to heirs.
Property that is of little value need not be placed in a living trust, because it may be exempt from probate or subject to a streamlined probate process. Most cars are not of high value and most insurance companies may be reluctant to insure a car owned by a trust. If, however, the car is of high value, it may make sense to check with the insurance company to see if it will insure cars owned by trusts. In any case, a Pour-Over Will generally covers the distribution of a car to heirs.
